nl.fw.yapool.socket

Class SocketAcceptor

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.fw.yapool.socket.SocketAcceptor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable

    public class SocketAcceptor
extends Object
implements Runnable
    A ServerSocket-thread that accepts incoming sockets and starts connection-tasks for them. Depending on the amount of open connections, a "too busy" flag is set which provides control over the limit of open connections and thus the work-load. Each socket is handled with 1 thread, which does not work for servers with many open connections like http-servers (use Jetty, Apache, Tomcat, etc.). It does however work when the amount of open connections is limited (up to about 500 on one machine).
    Author:
    frederikw

    • Method Detail

      • openSocketServer

        public boolean openSocketServer()
        This will open the server-socket (no sockets are accepted yet).
        Returns:
        true if the server-socket was opened and ready to accept incoming socket connections.

      • start

        public boolean start()
        Starts accepting incoming socket connections (uses getExecutor() to run this instance, if that returns null, a cached thread pool is created and set as executor).
        Before starting this method, you should call openSocketServer() and check the returned value. If openSocketServer() was not called previously, it is called by this method.
        Returns:
        true if this SocketAcceptor started, false otherwise.

      • startBlocking

        public boolean startBlocking()
        Same as start() but runs this socket server in the thread calling this method. After socket server is closed and this method returns, awaitTasks() should be called before closing the application.
        Returns:
        true if this SocketAcceptor started, false otherwise.

      • start

        protected boolean start(boolean blocking)

      • getSocketTask

        public SocketTask getSocketTask()
        The socket-task to execute for a new socket. This method returns a SocketTask by default. Overload this method to return a task that does something (you can extend SocketTask if you like).
        Creation of a socket-task object should be cheap as this method is called within the main server-socket thread. Also, it may not throw a runtime-exception else the main server-socket thread will exit.
        Socket tasks objects can be re-used with the help of an ObjectPool.
        Returns:
        the socket task to execute, never null.

      • taskDone

        public void taskDone()
        Method called from SocketTask to signal a task is done.

      • run

        public void run()
        The run-loop, should not be called directly (use start() method).
        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the server socket and all related workers. After first call the subsequent calls have no effect. This call is non-blocking, socket tasks may still be running.
        If awaitTasks() is not called, stop the getExecutor() manually if needed.

      • stopNow

        public void stopNow()
        Stops the server socket and all related workers immediatly, does not wait for tasks to finish.

      • stop

        protected void stop(boolean now)

      • closeServerSocket

        protected void closeServerSocket()
        Closes the server-socket and stops the getSocketUsageLogger() (if it was set). This method is synchronized, after the first call subsequent calls have no effect.

      • getRunError

        public Throwable getRunError()
        Returns:
        null or an unexpected exception that stopped the ServerSocket from working.

      • awaitTasks

        public int awaitTasks()
        Calls awaitTasks(long) with getCloseWaitTimeMs().

      • awaitTasks

        public int awaitTasks(long maxWaitTimeMs)
        Closes the server socket if it was not already closed and waits for tasks to stop running within the given maximum wait time in miliseconds.
        Logs info-messages at regular intervals which show the amount of open tasks. Closes the executor if isShutdownExecutorOnClose() is true.
        Returns:
        Amount of tasks that were still running after the maximum wait time was exceeded.

      • awaitRunningTasks

        protected void awaitRunningTasks(long maxWaitTimeMs)

      • shutdownExecutor

        protected void shutdownExecutor()
        Closes the getExecutor() but only if it isShutdownExecutorOnClose() is true and executor is of type ThreadPoolExecutor.

      • getPortNumber

        public int getPortNumber()
        Returns the configured port-number, the actual open port is returned by getOpenPort().

      • setPortNumber

        public void setPortNumber(int portNumber)
        The port-number to listen on for incoming sockets. Default 0 (which means "any available port").

      • getOpenPort

        public int getOpenPort()
        The port on which the server socket is listening.

      • getBackLog

        public int getBackLog()

      • setBackLog

        public void setBackLog(int backLog)
        The amount of sockets that can be waiting to be accepted. Default 50, set higher to prevent "connection refused" errors.

      • getAcceptedCount

        public long getAcceptedCount()
        The amount of sockets accepted.
